Message.Title: New investor dilemma
Message.Msg: Hey guys.. I'm saving for our very first house. There for I have a limited budget to spend on the stock market (3000$). That's all my girlfriend is willing to risk :). I can afford to lose this money and am ready to take some risk. This is my plan: I see AAPL going up with the iPhone 5 release in september and maybe the iPad mini and TV. I want to take full advantage of this so I was thinking to invest in a turbo with a leverage of 20 so I have about 100 shares with a stop loss of 620. Great risk, but the potential growth is big. ie if the price goes up to 700, I would make 5000$ profit and the stop loss will be far away. My dilemma is when to buy because the stop limit 620 is so close. Do you see a correction coming up this week with the goog lawsuit?

Topic.Title: New investor dilemma

Message.Msg: Hi. I have been an Apple investor since 2008, adding to my holding as and when I could. I sold all of my shares (1700) on April 5 this year, at a price of $626 - and posted this info' here on the board. With regard to your posting, and with all due respect, I think your girlfriend is correct when she tells you not to do this. You say you are saving for your very first house (home), then say can afford to lose $3000 on the market. You can't. Secondly, you are risking much in taking a turbo (leveraged) position. Yes, the upside is mouth-watering, but the downside is nightmare-ish. I think I understand your rationale - you are looking for quick profits (money) which will put you and your gf on track quicker. Please remember, the market owes you nothing, and there's no such thing as easy or quick money from it either. Also, please note that Apple have made NO comment regarding the release of a mini ipad, iTV or their iphone5. All this speculation has come from the media. Lastly, I am waiting to dip my toe in the water again and buy a few more Apple shares, but I will only do this AFTER their forthcoming presentation, and release of iphone5. I need to see how it is welcomed. Yes, I am missing this present run-up, but, for me, preservation of my profits to-date are more important. Giving back profits to the market hurts - giving principal is a killer. Take your girlfriend's advice - don't do it and focus on the home first.

Topic.Title: New investor dilemma

Message.Msg: Oh, one more point which I forgot to mention in my first post - a stop-loss does not always protect your position. Let's take a bad case: let's say that Apple shares close the day at $630 - ten dollars above your stop loss. After hours, bad news breaks - for whatever reason. Apple shares tumble. The following morning, Apple opens at, say, $570. This is the price you get - 570, not 620. That's 50 bucks below your stop loss position, and you are leveraged at 20x. Please be careful, OK.

Topic.Title: New investor dilemma

Message.Msg: i didnt realize they gave new investors leverage of 20:1. If the trade goes against you and your leveraged 20:1 then you will lose everything most likely. Why dont you just set up a normal trading account and put the money in there and buy shares with that money. You could do a normal margin account with 2:1 leverage. I have a margin account and I dont use it that much because if the trade goes against me I lose double the money I cant imagine having a 20:1 leverage account, that would pretty much be pure gambling. The returns would be great, but so will the risk. When I have my own money on the line I dont like to take such risks.Apple is a wonderful company and a great stock to own, but Apple can very easily drop 20-50 points within days. Ive been through many drops and while painful, I held on and eventally I made my money back holding on to the stock. If you are super leveraged and there is a big drop you have to sell and you will lose most of your money. In febuary I went all in on full margin, I put everything i had into apple *2:1 margin* It paid off very well, however it was risky as hell and down days on full margin were terrible. I dont do that anymore. You can lose a lot of money VERY QUICKLY on margin.

Message.Title: Buy the rumour is the key to Apple
Message.Msg: Prior to announcement, Apple should stay above 600 and I see 620's as the max low barring a collapse in the Dow/SP. If the market stays fairly flat or up into Sept 12., Apple should be at 680 max. After News somes selloff possible to 640s (assuming good news). If Apple announces first week sales as off the charts and there is very positive feedback on the phone, 750 is the number in my head. Always overshoots. Sell off of 20-30 points but at any point is possible as profit taking comes in. Big sellers are always there to knock the stock down. Higher volume could hep stabilize the stock. If the market is flat, traders will use Apple or whatever stock is moving so you can get more volatility. Obviously there are many factors but I would follow Cramers advice and dont trade Apple ... hold it. I sometimes will sell covered calls on half my positions and leave the others open. I also sell naked puts deep in the money for some extra money and cover lower down to reduce margin requirements. I want to bet the farm on Apple but there is always something to go wrong. Always keep that in mind. Best of luck.

I'd say if you have a time frame of more than 6 months to be on this stock, its not a problem, but if you want to invest on this unstable rumor, and gets a set back date that the next i phone will be out October instead of September...and you want your quick bucks right away?...You better not hang yourself because the next report on October will only include all revenues till end of September. I say that because the Apple deal with Authentec which is the mobile security for NFC (which is a huge feature of this next phone as rumored) has not been finalized by the share holders. I don't think Apple would feature NFC without the security of Authentec. AUTH shareholders (it includes yours truly) are not happy with the price we are getting from AAPLE. And everything is in a limbo. Unless Apple steps it up to pay up more to our liking just to get a Sept. date release of the iphone, and finalize the deal, then I would say the rumor is very very possible. This is my analysis. I think last year's announcement of the iphone was also delayed. So if this rally is making your palms itchy, I'd say invest on your own risk, tolerance and timeline . You can probably invest half now and half later? Message.Title: Google sues Apple: A must read. See Google news or Fortune
Message.Msg: FORTUNE -- So far, the "thermonuclear war" Steve Jobs promised to wage against Google (GOOG) for allegedly ripping off the iPhone has been fought through proxies -- several dozen lawsuits filed in courts around the world against the manufacturers of Android phones and tablets. Now, in a move rich with irony, Google has accused Apple (AAPL) of ripping off its patents. And rather than attacking a proxy, it has filed suit directly against Cupertino in the U.S. International Trade Commission. The claim, according to press statements issued to Bloomberg and the Wall Street Journal, is that Apple's iPhone, iPad and iPod Touch infringe seven of the roughly 17,000 patents Google inherited when it bought Motorola Mobility just over a year ago. "We would like to settle these patent matters," said a spokesperson for Google's Motorola division, "but Apple's unwillingness to work out a license leaves us little choice but to defend ourselves and our engineers' innovations." The filing has not yet been made public. and Google has been a little vague about what patents Apple may have infringed -- except to say that they are not the kind of standards-essential patents that Motorola had earlier tried and failed to use against Apple. (See here.) .....

Message.Title: The ECB Bazooka is ready to be launched
Message.Msg: The European Central Bank is weighing a plan to cap borrowing costs for struggling euro-zone governments by buying unlimited amounts of bonds, the German news magazine Der Spiegel reported Sunday. Such a move would mark an aggressive and controversial turn by the central bank in an effort to bring down borrowing costs for Spain and Italy. The report, which didn’t name sources, said the plan would see the ECB step in to buy bonds when the spread between yields on distressed government bonds moved above a certain, unspecified level versus German government debt. The report said the ECB Governing Council would decide at its September policy meeting whether to implement the plan, which would serve not only to prevent borrowing costs from climbing to unsustainable levels but also ensure that the spread between peripheral and core yields doesn’t grow too wide. ECB President Mario Draghi in a speech last month said the ECB would do “whatever it takes” within its mandate to preserve the euro. In the same speech, Draghi lamented that financial fragmentation within the euro zone had seen bond yields in some areas soar. That in turn distorts the transmission of the ECB’s monetary policy decisions, he said, putting the issue within the limits of the central bank’s price-stability mandate. Draghi earlier this month outlined a plan that would see the ECB buy government bonds in the secondary market provided strapped countries first apply for help to the region’s rescue funds and agree to abide by strict policy conditions. The rescue funds would then buy bonds in the primary market, an activity which the ECB is prohibited from undertaking. Time for shorts to bail,you do not have the power to fight the FED and the ECB

Albeit, Apple's first mistake was getting into bed with Samsung, if they are in fact going to come out with a TV. Additionally, not foreseeing Samsung stealing or copying the iPhone design was very inept on Apples part, and Samsung only needing to alter things just a bit to beat any infringement lawsuits is quite easy, as the DOJ is showing. Didn't they learn from MS long ago? However, nobody has the suite of products Apple does. The iPhone is an integral part of the entire experience, which will drive sales. Those who have the iPad most likely will also have an iPhone at some point. Remember, the analyst somehow lost sight of how many iPads would be purchased by the educational institutions - which is ridiculous since every major book publisher had been writing their textbooks for the IOS and app store, which aren't going in the scrapheap anytime soon, along with iTunes. Working in the Instructional Systems Technology area that deals with training and writing guides for educators, and corporations, Apple has the market in education cornered, that is a lot of kids being exposed to the Apple experience and growing up with the apple interface. What kind of phone would be the easiest and that emulates what is in their hands all day at school, to check in on their assignments, grades, create iMoves with that can easily be transferred to their iPad? Being in numerous schools the MAC stations are full every day with kids creating all things Apple - this isn't just about a phone. Im not saying this run up has caused a lot of insiders to bail, but this is the all-time high for Apple and people like to take some money off the table, as I have along the way. Nothing lasts forever, but Apple isn't done selling phones just yet.

Message.Title: iPhones to become real-money mobile casinos
Message.Msg: IPhones Become Mobile Casinos by Adding Real-Money Bets By Douglas MacMillan - Aug 16, 2012 10:00 AM ET IPhone users will soon be able to gamble with real money on virtual slot machines, trying their luck with the swipe of an index finger. Big Fish Games Inc. is introducing a version of its gambling application Big Fish Casino with real-money betting in the U.K., where it is legal, the Seattle-based company said. It will arrive in Apple Inc. (AAPL)’s App Store in the coming weeks, and Betable Ltd., a London-based partner of Big Fish, will process bets in the program. Game developers are building digital versions of Las Vegas casinos as users of smartphones and tablets are expected to wager $100 billion annually on the devices by 2017, up from about $20 billion last year, estimates Juniper Research. That potential payout has made Big Fish and other developers eager to replace virtual currencies with real cash in apps, even though use may be limited by gambling restrictions in the U.S. “This is the biggest opportunity that game developers have had since the advent of the Internet,” Christopher Griffin, chief executive officer of Betable, said in an interview. Big Fish may soon face competition from Zynga Inc. (ZNGA), the largest maker of social games, which last month said it plans to introduce real-money betting in the first half of 2013. Restrictions on Internet gambling in the U.S. may also ease, as several states, including California, Nevada and New Jersey, are considering legislation to legalize the practice. Game Makers In the U.K., companies including Betfair Group Plc (BET), and William Hill Plc (WMH) currently have gambling in iPhone apps. Betable is working with dozens of other game makers to debut real-money games this year, Griffin said. Big Fish Casino enables users to provide credit card numbers to place bets. Betable and Big Fish will divide the “take,” or the amount made on each slot machine wager. Even as Apple’s storefront plays host to an increasing number of casino apps, the Cupertino, California-based company isn’t taking a cut of sales from gambling in its apps, Tom Neumayr, a spokesman for Apple, said in an interview. Games are permitted in the App Store as long as they comply with local laws, said Neumayr, who declined to comment specifically on Big Fish. “Apple wants to keep arms’ length from this,” said Paul Thelen, CEO of Big Fish. “They don’t want to be the middleman in a gambling operation.” Last year, Apple prevented Big Fish from operating a subscription service that would have given iPad users access to dozens of video games for a monthly fee. Big Fish, founded in 2002, had revenue of more than $180 million last year, Thelen said. He expanded in online gambling with the March acquistion of Self Aware Games, a startup based in Oakland, California. Many players already pay real money for virtual currency in Big Fish games to bet on poker, slots and other games of chance, though they cannot cash out their winnings. These users are likely to flock to real-money wagers, Thelen said.

Topic.Title: Alert Alert...Samsung dropping like a Rock

Message.Msg: DO NOT TRUST ANYTHING FROM SAMSUNG. SAMSUNG IS A COPYCAT AND LIES ABOUT ITS SALES NUMBERS. Here's a quote from a recent Fortune article (MUST READ): Apple sold 5.7 million iPads in the U.S. last quarter, court docs show. Samsung sold 37,000 Tabs Reports of Galaxy Tab sales, like Mark Twain's death, have been greatly exaggerated FORTUNE -- In early December 2010, dozens of reporters happily repeated Samsung's claim that it had sold 1 million Galaxy Tab computers in the three and a half weeks since the tablet's November 2010 U.S. debut. Seven weeks later Samsung was telling analysts that Tab sales had passed 2 million. It's hard to reconcile those numbers with court documents Samsung filed Thursday in a California federal court that show the company selling 262,000 Galaxy Tabs in the U.S. -- the world's largest tablet market -- in Q4 2010 and 77,000 in Q1 2011. The discrepancy in the estimates of independent market researchers is even greater. According to an IDC press release issued just last week, Samsung sold 2,391,000 tablet computers worldwide in Q2 2012, up 117.6% from the same quarter last year. According to Samsung's court filing, it sold a total of 37,000 "accused" tablets (see UPDATE) in the U.S. last quarter, down 86% year over year.

Message.Title: Most mondays are down days. Important test for Apple
Message.Msg: Will sell off with the market but if it does better than the market, that would be a bullish sign and it is off to the races. This is too much of a sure thing. We are about 17 days away from the i5 announcement. The stock will not gown to 599 as there would be buying coming in by people who would be happy to have any pullback at this point. So the question is how low does Apple go before people say that is a good price. I would be buying on the first point of resistance. People will come in heavy on any rebound. Giving the stock a very strong resistance. I would keep 25 40% of your ammo dry and buy into any small dips. We are getting so close and each day less is a catalyst in its own right. There will be so much hype that the amount of free advertising from publicity is immeasurable. This alone could be a reason for selling many more phones. All iphone users will upgrade from now and 2 years forward. Over 90% of iphone users buy iphones again. Some people having been waiting much longer seeing no reason to buy a phone that has not upgraded that much. If the I5 is a fantastic upgrade, this stock will hit 800 in a blink of an eye. Apple will be on its way to over 1000 by yearend. So the pivot point is the revealing of the phone. If it is great, buying would come in on a massive scale. I don't think Apple would drop much and that drop would be bought right back up. Apple might come out i with a press release saying they sold a gazillion phones during the first 5 days or something like that. That on top of talk of revised earnings for the Sept ending quarter and speculation on Decembers ending qtr. Finally, any ipad mini, itv, etc extra positive news or even an actual release of a new product will be massive. Also, introduction of iphone5 to other demographics (ie China/China Mobile) will only fuel the rapid advance that Apple is most likely experiencing.

Message.Title: Equity funds lost another 6.3 billion last week.
Message.Msg: Market makers have inflated the DJI and S&P to draw more suckers in...Should be selling into strength here. From Yahoo Finance... Still, the unwillingness of retail investors to participate in the rally is striking. Market volume on the New York Stock Exchange has hit 2012 lows in recent sessions and is about half of where it was for the same week a year ago. Options volume is down about 11 percent, while trading activity at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange is off 30 percent from its 2011 pace, according to financial services firm Keefe, Bruyette & Woods. Fund flows have told a similar story: Equity funds, including exchange-traded funds, lost another $6.3 billion last week while bond funds took in $3 billion, according to Lipper. Stock funds lost $11.5 billion in the second quarter while bond funds gained $55.4 billion. "The individual investor is still not in," said Keith Springer, president of Springer Financial Advisory in Sacramento, Calif. "At some point there could be some panic buying by some individuals if they gain confidence. But the average investor doesn't believe in this."

Message.Title: Bad news on China from Bill Kristol - Weekly Standard
Message.Msg: If you must ask how this affects Apple or any other stock, you should NOT be in equities. 1) China’s economy is not just slowing, it is entering a serious correction. The investment bubble that has been driving Chinese growth has popped, and there are no quick “stimulus” fixes left. There is the very real possibility of some form of financial crisis in China before year’s end. 2) China is in the midst of a once-in-a-decade leadership transition that has not been going smoothly. The transition will take place, but it has paralyzed the Chinese leadership’s ability to respond to the country’s growing economic troubles. China’s leaders believe time is on their side; they do not “get” how serious and urgent the situation is, and that what has always “worked” is no longer working. 3) China’s economic problems spell trouble for the U.S. on several fronts. First, China is flirting with devaluing its currency to boost exports—a move that will put it in direct conflict with Mitt Romney’s commitments on this issue. Second, China is already dumping excess capacity in steel and other products onto the export market, a tactic that is likely to inflame trade tensions and reinforce imbalances in the global economy. Third, in a worst case scenario, China may be tempted to provoke a conflict in the South China Sea to redirect popular discontent onto an external enemy.

Message.Title: Apple's Secrecy - How is it possible?

These Foxconn workers really do not get paid much and the temptation to release secrets and smuggle pix out just seems too tempting. Yet, it rarely ever happens.
